Kangra

Kangra is Himachal’s wide valley district, spread between low Shivalik hills and the high Dhauladhar range. It has everything in one place: tea gardens, old forts, Tibetan monasteries, busy markets, and quiet rural belts. People here live between farming, small businesses, government jobs, and seasonal tourism. Life feels more spread out than in other districts; one side touches Punjab’s plains, the other side looks straight at the snow.

Our Hidden Favourites

  • Masroor Rock-Cut Temples - About 35 km from Kangra town, Masroor is a group of stone temples carved from a single rock. Many outsiders miss it. Locals go there for quiet darshan and to sit by the small water tank in front.
  • Bathu Ki Ladi - In the Pong Dam backwaters, the Bathu temples stay underwater most of the year. When water levels fall (usually late spring or summer), the stone temples stand out again. People from nearby villages go by boat or track to visit. It is very seasonal and very local.
  • Neugal & Gunehar side - Around Gopalpur and Bir, short walks lead to small spots locals like Neugal-side temples and Gunehar waterfall. These are simple picnic or walk places, not developed tourist spots.
  • Sidhbari & Gopalpur - Sidhbari has the Chinmaya Mission temple with its golden idol, and views of the Dhauladhar. Gopalpur is a calm village with a zoo nearby and trail starts for local hikes. Many people from Dharamshala area go here on Sundays rather than to the more crowded McLeod market.
  • Local Daily-Use Spots - There are many more such "daily-use" places, small ridge temples, village ponds, and local mela grounds that matter more to people here than the main tourism points.

Towns & Villages

  • Kangra Town (Tira Kangra) - Sits below the old, large Kangra Fort, the main landmark. The bazaars (Lamba Market and Kotwali) are for locals, selling everything from groceries to Kangri paintings. It feels like a working town.
  • Dharamshala & McLeod Ganj - Lower Dharamshala (HQ) holds courts, offices, and the main bus stand. Upper Dharamshala (McLeod Ganj) hosts the Dalai Lama's residence, monasteries, and Tibetan shops. Local Himachali life blends into the background behind the main tourist streets.
  • Palampur - Known for its tea gardens and mild weather. Canals run through the fields where people grow maize, wheat, and vegetables alongside tea. It is also a key education hub, giving it a lively student population.
  • Baijnath - A smaller town famous for its ancient Shiva temple. Outside of major festivals, it remains a quiet place with a main market and the river nearby.
  • Nurpur & Dera Gopipur - Nurpur is close to the Punjab border, featuring an old fort and temple. Dera Gopipur, on the Beas, is slower, known for riverside ghats and old temples.
  • Andretta, Bir, Pragpur–Garli -
    Andretta: An art and pottery village. Norah Richards and later Sobha Singh made it an artist’s pocket in the valley. Today, pottery workshops and small homestays keep that culture alive.
    Bir: Started as a quiet village with fields and monasteries. Now it is known for paragliding, but behind the main road, it is still just a Himachali–Tibetan village with cows, wheat fields, and monks walking to prayer.
    Pragpur and Garli: Heritage villages with old havelis, slate roofs, and narrow streets. Families still live in these homes, run small shops, and host simple stays.
  • Local Villages - Between these centers, hundreds of villages exist where daily life revolves simply around farming, school, temple, and the local market.

Culture & Festivals

  • Cultural Mix: Kangra’s culture is a mix of Pahari traditions and Tibetan influence near Dharamshala. Most people are Hindu, but Tibetan Buddhists, Sikhs, and Christians all live side by side.
  • Baijnath Shivratri Fair: A big gathering at the Baijnath temple featuring wrestling, local bands, food stalls, and late-night aarti.
  • Palampur Holi: Celebrated with colorful parades through the town, decorated tractors or floats, and groups singing and dancing.
  • Chait / Dholru (Spring): Families sing folk songs and beat small drums to symbolically send away winter’s bad luck and mark the end of the season.
  • Baisakhi / Biswa: Houses are cleaned, walls whitewashed, and some families take a holy dip in rivers and streams like Ban-Ganga.
  • Sair (Harvest): A small harvest fair in mid-September where people carry fruits and grains to local temples to thank the gods for the crop.
  • Lohri in Pragpur–Garli: Families gather around bonfires, throw peanuts and sweets into the fire, and share traditional snacks like rewri and gachak.
  • Tibetan Festivals (McLeod Ganj): Tibetan Buddhists celebrate Losar (New Year) with butter lamps and new prayer flags, and the Himalayan Festival with folk performances and crafts.
  • Daily Religious Life: Most religious life is simple: morning and evening aarti at village temples, occasional local jagran, and annual devta yatra (procession) when the local deity is carried around the village.

Education & Youth

  • University Presence: Kangra hosts the Central University of Himachal Pradesh (CUHP) in Dharamshala and Dehra. Palampur has an engineering college and a veterinary university.
  • College Network: General degree colleges, nursing colleges, and B.Ed colleges are located in major towns including Dharamshala, Palampur, Kangra, Nurpur, and Jaisinghpur.
  • Migration for Opportunity: Many students travel to Chandigarh, Delhi, or other cities for specialized courses or coaching, seeking larger career opportunities.
  • Career Paths: A large number of young men join the Army or police. Others pursue jobs in tourism and hospitality. Many young people take driving or hotel-related jobs. Some go to the Gulf or other countries for work.
  • Local Skill Development: Local ITIs and skill centers train youth in hospitality, computers, and trades. A portion of them stays back to work in cafes, homestays, and small businesses around Dharamshala, Palampur, and Bir.
  • Demographics: In many villages, working-age people are away, leaving behind mostly elders and children during the day.

Our Stories

Exploring the majestic peaks of the Himalayas, capturing breathtaking moments.

Immersing ourselves in the rich culture and vibrant traditions of Himachal Pradesh.

Food & Markets

  • Daily Cuisine: Food is home-style and filling. Daily meals include wheat rotis or rice, dal (often mixed), and seasonal sabzi (pumpkin, ghiya, saag, radish leaves, cauliflower, etc.). Meals are often accompanied by homemade pickles and chutneys.
  • Special Dishes (Dham Items):
    • Chha Gosht – Mutton cooked slowly in a spiced curd gravy.
    • Madra – Rajma or chana cooked in thick yogurt with mild spices.
    • Bhey – Thin sliced lotus stem cooked with masala.
    • Khatta – Slightly sour black gram preparation, common in the traditional dham.
  • Kangri Dham Feast: During weddings and big fairs, people serve Kangri Dham on leaf plates, which typically includes rice, dal, madra, khatta, boor ki kadi, and meetha chawal (sweetened rice).
  • Market Goods:
    • Lamba Market, Kangra: Known for shawls, brassware, local paintings, and daily-use clothes.
    • Kotwali Bazaar, Dharamshala: Sells groceries, pulses, spices, dry fruits, and features small eateries.
    • Palampur & Nurpur: Main produce includes tea, fruits (peach, plum, apple, pear), and dairy products.
  • Local Trade: Every town and many big villages have a weekly *haat*. Farmers bring vegetables and grains, and buy spices, shoes, and household items.
  • Eateries: Dhabas and small restaurants serve simple thalis (dal, sabzi, rice, and roti). In Tibetan belts (McLeod Ganj, Bir), momos and thukpa are widely available.
  • Local Tea: **Kangra tea** from Palampur-side gardens is popular in local homes and shops, preferred strong but not bitter, with milk and sugar.

Respect & Etiquette

  • Greetings: Greet with "Ram Ram," "Namaste," or "Jai Ram ji ki" with folded hands. Kangra people are straightforward and polite.
  • Sacred Spaces:
    • Remove shoes before entering temples and monasteries.
    • Dress modestly in temples.
    • Do not touch idols or sacred objects unless instructed.
    • Ask before taking photos, especially during rituals or inside prayer halls.
  • Public Conduct: Do not litter. Keep music low in village areas, especially near temples and after dark.
  • Photography: Always ask before photographing people, especially women, children, or monks.
  • Market Conduct: Be polite in markets; bargaining is normal but keep the tone soft.
  • General Approach: Move with a calm pace, greet elders with respect, and avoid disturbing local customs.
